overview_of_class: The word "classical" in the course title refers to "ancient Greek." Arguments about such things as justice, liberty, security, authority, power, legitimacy, membership, virtue and equality are part of political life. But what does it mean to think theoretically about political matters? What does it mean to have a deep political conviction that can stand public scrutiny? What distinguishes rigorous deliberation from hurling opinions? These questions animate the entire history of the intellectual enterprise known as "political theory" from antiquity to today and across geographic and cultural divides. This course introduces students to the political institutions of the period that produced a globally influential written record of sustained reflection on these issues. In particular, this course will address the shape of citizen-centered politics in Greek antiquity (in democracies and oligarchies, and with attention to practices such as tragedy and comedy at dramatic festivals and patterns of military service, as well as governing institutions like open-air assemblies and majority rule) and engage students in examination of three great texts (Thucydides' "History of the Peloponnesian War," Plato's "Republic" and Aristotle's "Politics."). The contemporary 21st century resonances of these sources will also receive attention.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Students will gain skills necessary to examine arguments about politics in a rational and theoretically sophisticated manner. They will also gain familiarity with the characteristics of citizen-centered politics in Greek antiquity, the practice of critique generated in this period and an appreciation for this material's continuing relevance.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Discussion, written work, final creative project due in exam week

Plato Republic Penguin ISBN 978-0-141-44243-3;
Aristotle, Politics (new edition by Hackett).

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: Attendance at the first class is required. Final exam slot during exam week will be used to present final projects (not sit a written exam) .
